title: Where does the best cheese come from? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve been around, and from what I can see, it seems that europe is a land of cheese and wine. One can find a good cheese all over the continent. Some of the more famous ones: Feta in greece and similar salty cheeses in Macedonia (“Belo Sirenje”), Bulgaria, south Serbia..Halloumi - the only cheese that I know of that can be grilled like a piece of meat.Gorgonzola, Parmigiano-Reggiano, Mozzarella di Bufalo, Provolone, etc - there are dosens of really good cheese types in italy (see List of Italian cheeses)Pag cheese in Croatia, Livno cheese in Bosnia, Kashkaval in Serbia, Bulgaria & Macedonia..Famous Edamer & Gouda from Netherlands (see also List of Dutch cheeses)Emmentaler and 400+ other types in Swizerland (see List of Swiss cheeses)And so on. Every european country has a couple of really good cheese types and the cheese is omnipresent all over the continent. Some are common all over the place, like Feta or Emmentaler. Other are more peculiar, like the Steirerkäse – Wikipedia (there are worse things, but this one is already not something to be taken lightly). However, among all these places there is one country that is the real kingdom of cheese and wine: France. It’s not just that french produce huge number of cheese types that really differ in look and taste (List of French cheeses). It’s not just the enormous quantity of wine & cheese that they produce either. What makes France into a wine & cheese world champion is that they are essential part of the french cultural identity. If you ever get a chance to visit a Foire aux Fromages et aux Vins | Ville d'Antony (or similar in other places), by all means do. I have learned more about french way of life there than anywhere else. :-) Update: what just occurred to me is that by the cheese index, Turkey is definitely an European country. Plenty of good cheese there.

The best cheeses all come from one place: an udder. That's right, whether it be a cheddar cheese made from cow's milk, a mozzarella made from buffalo milk, a creamy goat's milk spread, or a salty and sharp sheep's milk Romano, the best cheeses are based on the milk of ruminants. Now, there are some imitators out there, made from plant milks like coconut or almond milk, but these have never tasted as good as the real deal to warrant a look, unless you were concientious in your motivations to go animal free. The only even slightly contender, which some might argue is a cheese, since it is a form of congealed soy milk, which is pressed to remove water, is tofu. Tofu serves a niche market, as the type of “cheese” served in many Asian dishes. It does well, but is fairly flavorless, so does not do very well without outside flavor help.(And, yes, I know there is a flavorful, “stinky” variety of tofu, but let's save that for a future discussion, as tofu is such a friend cheese to begin with)

I have spent a good portion of my life in the Canadian dairy industry, in specific mostly in Cheese industry. I like to say a few words on this topic: No single country can take the title: Which country makes the best cheese? There are a few major countries who are on the forefront of cheese making/technology/history of cheese making/ innovations and mastery in the arts and science of cheese making Italy: Number one in cheeses for cooking and baking, which is the technical/Italian we call “ Pasta Filata” type cheese or in English we call these cheeses as “Stretched Curd” category. Prime examples Mozzarella, Provolone, and caciocavallo type cheeses. Grated cheeses: Romano and Parmesan type cheeses. France: Number one: In Table Cheeses and endless varieties Examples, List of French cheeses - Wikipedia  Greece: Number one, in Feta cheese. Switzerland: Number One, in Swiss Cheese. Netherlands: Number one, in Gouda/Edam. U.K.: Number one, in Cheddar type cheeses. USA: Mega quantity producer of cheese. Honorable mention of New Zealand.

A French sommellier told me a few years ago that they used to produce the best cheese in the world, now the British do. We have a long history of cheesemaking which almost disappeared during world war 2. There are no holey cheeses or Parmesan like cheeses in the collection, but there are plenty of other great choices. You could easily produce a restaurant cheese board from British cheeses: Blue: Blacksticks blue or Cropwell Bishop StiltonSoft / semi soft: Stinking BishopHard: Farmhouse CheddarGoat: InnesHaving said all that, why limit the cheese to one country? There amazing cheeses in most parts of the world and they all deserve a place on the cheese board.

This is an impossible question to answer as it’s so subjective but does raise an important point. France has long been hailed as the home of great traditional cheeses. However, in recent years there has been a huge growth in innovation with and appreciation of artisanal cheese making. The French appellation system and that of some other countries has in many ways stifled this creativity, allowing other nations to become greater innovators. On a purely personal level, the current small artisanal cheese makers of Ireland represent the most exciting place right now. Try some and enjoy.

The country with the single best cheese of the planet is Serbia. The name of the best cheese there is magareći sir (donkey cheese), and is made with 60% donkey milk and 40% goat milk. Its flavour is sweet, clean and mild, unlike any cheese anywhere that I had ever tasted, and I did taste most of them from around the world. Otherwise no country can compares with France, wich has probably some 9oo different kind of cheese, and I´m not counting privately done cheese, wich every farm make at home. Something rather normal in the country side.

Ask a thousand people who like cheese and you'll end up with probably 500 answer. Best blue cheese comes from England, France, or Italy.Best hard cheese comes from Italy, or maybe Spain.Best soft cheese comes from France, or Germany, or maybe the USBest 'very strange' cheese comes from Norway or Switzerland

Oh that's definitely a tie between France and Great Britain. So many great choices. Vacheron and Brie deMeaux . Stinking Bishop and Huntsman. All that creamy richness comes from centuries of tradition and happy cows. Nearly a cheese for every district and province. All full of character which must be tasted.

Of course it's France. In France,there are more than three hundreds types of cheese. They can taste a different type of cheese every day in their daily life. The famous general Charles d gaulle once said, it's hard to governer a country which has more than three hundreds types of cheese .

Even as an Italian (mostly), I would say it’s a tossup between Italy and France. I love Italian cheeses — grana padano, pecorino romano, Parmigiano-Reggiano, Robiola, Taleggio, gorgonzola dolce latte, and on and on. But the French have to rank high if only for the sheer quantity of great cheese: Roquefort, Pont L’eveque, Comte, Camembert, Morbier, Reblochon, etc. What more can I say?
A little shop in England.   On second thought, it might be best to try Neal's Yard.
